;;卢浮宫警戒线
;

;数千名游客已从巴黎卢浮宫疏散博物馆工作人员收到书面威胁。

;

;周六发出警告时，法国正处于;恐怖袭击的最高警报;;周五，一名教师在该国北部被一名疑似激进伊斯兰分子杀害;。

;

;博物馆表示，“出于安全原因”，整个下午都将关闭，在估计有 15,000 人被指示离开后，警察和工作人员正在对建筑物进行“核实”。

;

;卢浮宫官员表示，他们已经周六早上收到一封书面信息，“指出博物馆及其游客面临风险”。他们表示，它“选择撤离并关闭当天，以便进行必要的检查”，并补充说，那些预订了参观门票的人将得到报销。

;

;正在部署多达 7,000 名士兵随着本周末恐怖威胁的出现，全国各地都受到了影响。周五早上，57 岁的法国文学教师多米尼克·伯纳德 (Dominique Bernard) 在阿拉斯甘贝塔-卡诺中学的庭院里被刺死。另外三名工作人员受伤，其中两人伤势严重。伯纳德是三个孩子的父亲，自 20 世纪 80 年代以来一直在这所学校任教。

;

;一名 20 岁的前学生，名叫穆罕默德 M，出生于俄罗斯以穆斯林为主的北高加索地区，现已被捕并被拘留正在接受反恐警察的询问。他已被列入法国 Fiche S 安全名单，被列为疑似激进伊斯兰分子，并受到严密监视，包括电话窃听。周四，警方拦截并搜查了他，但没有找到拘留他的理由。

;

;卢浮宫是世界上最大的博物馆，也是达芬奇的《蒙娜丽莎》、断臂维纳斯雕像和许多其他雕像的所在地。国际公认的杰作，每天访问量高达40,000人次。

;德国财政部长已向英国发出公开邀请，以达成一项协议改善英国退欧贸易关系的新协议将减少贸易壁垒和“日常商业生活中的障碍”。

;

;克里斯蒂安·林德纳 (Christian Lindner) 告诉 BBC：“这是对英国的长期邀请：如果您想加强与欧盟的贸易关系，请致电我们。我们真的很欣赏英国及其价值观、人民……如果我们能够再次加强[贸易关系]，我真的非常非常感激。”

;

;他的评论将会令欧洲人感到惊讶。欧盟委员会副主席马罗什·塞夫科维奇 (Maroš Šefčovič) 负责英国脱欧贸易协议的谈判，他们向工党领袖基尔·斯塔默 (Keir Starmer) 敞开了大门，后者表示，如果赢得下届大选，他将寻求与欧盟建立“更好”的关系选举。

;
;

;;相关：;;德国支持英国和欧盟之间推迟电动汽车销售关税;

;
;

;Šefčovič 坚称英国脱欧协议不会被“扔进粉碎机”。他还抵制英国和欧盟汽车行业要求对电动汽车出口暂停征收关税三年的呼吁，关税定于 1 月份生效。

;

;据了解，他可能，不过，同意暂停一年作为妥协。

;

;林德纳表示，英国脱欧给“日常商业生活造成了障碍”，并使与英国的贸易变得更加困难。

;

;“在德国企业的日常生活中，自英国脱欧以来出现了新的障碍......我认为英国不会从英国脱欧中受益。”他说。

;

;专家表示，即使没有根源和英国上议院英国上议院;今年早些时候确定了 72 个可以改进的领域;，包括为巡演音乐家和戏剧表演者提供更宽松的签证安排，恢复对会计师等专业人士资格的相互承认，并放宽访问学童的规则。

;

;林德纳的评论是欧盟最大经济体之一首次提出脱欧协议鲍里斯·约翰逊和大卫·弗罗斯特的谈判也损害了欧盟企业。

;

;人们担心德国经济已经发生变化;陷入“缓慢衰退”;，预计今年经济将因高通胀、高能源价格和国际贸易疲软。

;

;政府在 4 月份的预测中预计 2023 年经济增长 0.4%，但;工业;和十年来的最高利率引发了人们对欧元区最大经济体今年再次陷入衰退的担忧。< /p>;

;根据英国政府9月份公布的统计数据，德国是英国第二大贸易伙伴，占英国贸易总额的8%。

;

;日常贸易成本已经发生变化，然而，英国离开单一市场后需要海关和标准文件和认证。

;

;汽车行业有;呼吁暂停悬而未决的关税三年;，但欧盟存在分歧。其负责内部市场的专员蒂埃里·布雷顿 (Thierry Breton) 最近告诉《卫报》，它无法为一个行业提供相对于另一个行业的特殊保护。

;

;批评者表示，汽车行业才是罪魁祸首，而不是英国脱欧协议。加速 ;制造电动汽车电池所需的化学品;，并让中国竞争对手抢先一步。

;

;英国政府发言人表示：“这项贸易与合作协议是世界上最重要的协议最大的零关税、零配额自由贸易协定。

;

;“它确保了英国关键服务行业的市场准入，并为英国企业在全球范围内开辟了新的机会。

;

;“以下在温莎框架下，英国和欧盟都公开承诺进一步最大限度地利用 TCA 的机会。”

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 20:22:02 +0800 London police defy ban on badges linked to far right and white supremacyhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/14/london-police-defy-ban-on-badges-linked-to-far-right-and-white-supremacy

;
;;伦敦警察厅的警察被禁止佩戴英国的细蓝线符号，因为它已被右翼团体盗用。;

;伦敦警察厅的警察公然违抗不得佩戴极右派侵占的、与白人至上主义相关的徽章的命令。

;

;7 月，警察局长马克·罗利 (Mark Rowley) 禁止警察佩戴“细蓝线”徽章表示，在美国，“极右翼团体”使用了类似的符号。

;

;然而，上个月末出现的大都会警察在执勤时佩戴该符号的图片- LGBTQ+ 权利支持者与右翼团体就伦敦南部刘易舍姆 Honor Oak 酒吧的变装表演发生争执。

;

;活动人士表示，英国转折点组织的抗议活动中的警察“令人担忧” (TPUK) 认为他们可以挑战罗利的权威而明显不受惩罚。

;

;在美国，警方对细蓝线符号的使用已被证明是分裂的，一些部队在将其戴在口罩上后禁止使用该符号。负责“黑人生命也是命”抗议活动的警察，这个符号也出现在 ;2017 年在弗吉尼亚州夏洛茨维尔举行的白人至上主义集会;和 ;2021 年美国国会大厦发生叛乱;。

;

;不过，英国警察佩戴它得到了内政大臣苏埃拉的支持布雷弗曼对罗利禁止佩戴徽章的做法提出了质疑，并在最近的保守党会议演讲中特别赞扬了枪械警察，将他们描述为“细细的蓝线”。

;

;她提到的枪械警察让数百人感到担忧。上个月临时服役的伦敦警察局官员 ;在一名同事被指控谋杀 24 岁的克里斯·卡巴 (Chris Kaba)，后者于去年 9 月被枪杀后，他辞去了职务;。

;

;罗利禁止他的军官佩戴这种徽章——一面黑白联盟旗一条细细的水平蓝线——在对骄傲庆祝活动进行监管之前，担心它可能会冒犯 LGBTQ+ 群体。

;

;在右翼团体抗议变装讲故事的活动中，警察选择在敏感的警务期间佩戴它。活动人士称，“那个女孩”的行为具有明显的挑衅性。

; ;

;一个在抗议活动中佩戴徽章的警官被拍到在右翼活动家劳伦斯福克斯旁边，几天前他发表了;关于政治记者艾娃·埃文斯 (Ava Evans) 的厌恶女性言论;。

;

;凯文·布洛 (Kevin Blowe)，警察监控网络 (Netpol) 协调员，该组织与社区合作揭露暴力和压迫性警务，该组织表示：“在 Honor Oak 的特殊情况下，显然需要提高敏感度，而命令不被遵守的事实令人担忧。

;

;“如果你布洛补充说，事实上，一些警官有足够的胆量，尽管罗利试图改变警察部队的文化，但大都会警察认为丑陋的心态仍然存在，今年早些时候的一份报告将其描述为;制度上仇视同性恋、厌恶女性和种族主义;。

;

;布洛补充道：“警察内部存在一种普遍心态，这种心态比少数警官要广泛得多，而且对警官的行为方式基本上缺乏责任感。”

;

;在另一场荣誉橡树抗议活动中八月，即罗利对细蓝线的佩戴进行干预后的一个月，一名警官被发现戴着凯尔特十字，这是一种常见的白人至上符号，被世界各地的新纳粹分子使用。

;

;然而，英国其他警察部队也将细蓝线作为积极的象征——它是为了纪念阵亡警官而创建的——警察局长愿意为他的警官支付这样的徽章。北安普敦郡警察局长尼克·阿德利 (Nick Adderley) 表示，他不会允许少数人“扭曲该徽章的含义”，该徽章由“关心警察幸存者”慈善机构制作，并出售以为在前线牺牲的警察家属筹集资金。已联系大都会博物馆征求意见。

;

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 20:22:02 +0800 ‘It’s a poor product ’: leading UK chefs join campaign to cast farmed salmon off menuhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/14/its-a-poor-product-leading-uk-chefs-join-campaign-to-cast-farmed-salmon-off-menu
;;2023-10-14T10:00:39Z;
;
;;养殖鲑鱼。
;

;近几十年来，鲑鱼经历了快速转变。它曾经是一种特殊的享受，现在却无处不在。从饮料招待会小吃到婚礼活动、圣诞节熏鲑鱼或简单地用箔纸包裹并在一周的晚上烘烤，鲑鱼无处不在。

;

;苏格兰以鲑鱼生产闻名于世，鲑鱼占鲑鱼产量的 40%粮食出口总额；它也是英国最有价值的出口食品。三文鱼健康、饱和脂肪含量低、omega-3 含量高，是一个成功的典范。

;

;然而，越来越多的顶级厨师开始拒绝这种粉红色肉质的大众美食——被称为“世界之鸡”。一些人认为“海洋”——引用了鲑鱼养殖的环境和福利问题，包括对使用抗生素和化学品的担忧；大量原本可以被人类食用的野生鱼类被用作饲料；它在野生鲑鱼数量下降中的作用；和缺乏质量。

;

;从德文郡到苏格兰，餐馆、咖啡馆、画廊和酒店都放弃了养殖鲑鱼。他们包括格蕾丝和西米德兰兹郡索利哈尔的米其林星级餐厅 Savour、伦敦东部的零浪费餐厅 Silo、著名的“从头到尾”的 St John 餐厅集团、泰特美术馆和布里斯托尔的 Poco Tapas 酒吧（由;卫报;专栏作家;Tom Hunt;.

; ;

;“我认为这是一种很差的产品，而且由于它对野生鲑鱼有影响，我不会提供它，”;爱丁堡的帕默斯顿餐厅;。

;

;自 20 世纪 70 年代以来，英国的野生大西洋鲑鱼数量急剧下降”WildFish 慈善机构的马特·帕尔默 (Matt Palmer) 说道。WildFish 是一家慈善机构，鼓励餐厅加入其“Off the table”活动，目前已有 150 多家餐厅参与其中。 “工业化鲑鱼养殖是导致这种下降的原因之一。”

;

;帕尔默曾在鲑鱼养殖场担任兽医，他列举了养殖场中生长的寄生海虱，它们可以传播和感染野生鲑鱼和海鳟鱼，有时会造成致命的后果。

;

;苏格兰鱼类健康检查局的一份报告发现，苏格兰养鱼场的死亡;与前一年相比，2022 年几乎翻了一番;，达到 1500 万。海水温度上升和微型水母被认为是今年养殖鲑鱼产量下降 18% 的原因，批评者认为，过度拥挤和在鱼完全长大之前屠宰鱼是不道德的。

;
;

; ;相关：;;“怪物”海虱和水母入侵给苏格兰鲑鱼养殖场造成了严重打击;

;
;

;Salmon Scotland 是苏格兰鲑鱼行业的代言人，他们认为海虱会影响养殖鲑鱼和野生鲑鱼，以及其他鲑鱼。野生鲑鱼数量减少的原因包括水质、气候危机和栖息地丧失。报告还称，苏格兰鲑鱼的饲养密度是世界上最低的。

;

;在德文郡蒂弗顿的 Lost Kitchen，鲑鱼是菜单上长期的主菜。这家拥有80个座位的餐厅以柴火烹饪为主，自家热熏三文鱼深受顾客喜爱。 “三文鱼是一种体型大、肉质好、烹饪效果非常好的鱼，”经理兼联合创始人乔治·艾克罗伊德 (George Aykroyd) 说道。 “这可能真的很微妙。高温意味着你可以更快地密封外部并保持内部水分，从而获得蒸熟的柔软中心。”

;

;但在三月份，该餐厅放弃了最受欢迎的产品之一。 “我们认为存在如此多的信息，作为企业我们有责任，”艾克罗伊德说。 “这不是鲑鱼的问题，而是鲑鱼的生产过程。海中大网少量的鲑鱼是一件好事，但现在看来是小网大数量的鲑鱼。”

;

;康沃尔养殖鳟鱼几乎是无缝互换，即使周围有三分之一的顾客最初询问为什么三文鱼被移除。鳟鱼现已成为畅销产品，没有一位客人在尝试后抱怨过。 “我们认为使用康沃尔郡的一个非常小的养鱼场在淡水中养殖鳟鱼更为明智，”艾克罗伊德说。 “我们去过并看到过它。”

;

;莫尔斯在澳大利亚长大，对英国鲑鱼的数量感到惊讶。 “这种现象在这里非常普遍，”他说。据海洋保护协会 (MCS) 称，鲑鱼是英国消费最广泛的鱼类，与之前的鸡肉一样，集约化养殖刺激了人们的食欲。 “90 年代笼养母鸡是一件大事，为什么这里没有同样的比较呢？”莫尔斯说。

;

;除了环境问题之外，莫尔斯的主要抱怨之一是它是一种“糟糕的产品”。相反，他在季节时使用野生海鳟鱼：“它们令人惊叹，美味 - 这是粉笔和奶酪。”他提供的不是熏鲑鱼、鳕鱼和腌鳕鱼。

; ;

;Chantelle Nicholson，伦敦市中心可持续餐厅 Apricity 的主厨兼老板，过去供应鲑鱼定期在她以前的场地特雷德韦尔斯 (Tredwells) 举行。 “这很受欢迎。如果你把它放在菜单上，它就会畅销，”她说。但据报道使用抗生素促使她把鱼去掉。

;

;“现在有一些非常好的替代品。粉笔溪鳟鱼很相似，但味道更好，而且质地可爱。”尼克尔森说道，她的海鲜产品主要选择用线捕获的鲭鱼和贻贝。

;

;苏格兰鲑鱼表示 95% 2021 年，海水养殖场根本没有使用抗生素。 MCS 和海洋管理委员会都没有主张全面抵制。 MCS 在其红绿灯系统中将有机和水产养殖管理委员会认证的大西洋鲑鱼评为“绿色”，而大多数其他养殖鲑鱼评为“琥珀色”，这意味着需要改进。

;

;MSC 的可持续蓝勾适用只销售野生鲑鱼产品，大部分来自北美。

;

;“苏格兰鲑鱼是英国最受欢迎的鱼类，也是英国第一大食品出口产品，”Salmon Scotland 首席执行官塔维什·斯科特 (Tavish Scott) 说道。他补充道：“随着国内和全球对苏格兰三文鱼的需求持续增长，苏格兰三文鱼行业的成功以及依赖该行业的就业岗位不会受到少数城市激进厨师的威胁。”< /p>; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 20:22:02 +0800 ‘People are dying in the street’: Ecuador election overshadowed by violent crimehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/14/ecuador-presidential-election-violence-crime

;;2023-10-14T11:00:41Z;
;
;;女性在投票站外投票
;

;厄瓜多尔人将在本周末在中右翼总统候选人之间进行选择他是该国最富有的家族之一的后裔，也是前总统拉斐尔·科雷亚的左翼弟子，这次选举因暴力犯罪和第三位候选人被暗杀而蒙上阴影。

;

;周日投票前的民意调查显示，香蕉产业继承人 Daniel Noboa，35 岁，略领先于 Luisa González，后者承诺提供免费药品并加强对工人的保护。

;
;

;;相关：;;厄瓜多尔犯罪团伙在政治僵局中带来死亡和混乱;

;
;

;;2023-10-14T10:04:30Z;
;
;;Chris Hipkins
;

;新西兰工党领袖 Chris Hipkins 承认他的政党输掉了选举中右翼国家党的支持率激增，分析人士称这对政府来说是一场“大屠杀”。

;

;希普金斯在惠灵顿举行的选举之夜活动上发表讲话，希普金斯于 1 月份成为工党领袖杰辛达·阿德恩（Jacinda Ardern）意外辞职后表示，他已致电反对党领袖克里斯托弗·卢克森（Christopher Luxon）祝贺他的选举结果。

;

;“就目前情况而言，工党无法组建另一个政府，”他说。 “The result is not one any of us wanted.”

;

;New Zealand's election results on Saturday showed a drastic swing to the right, with a coalition of the centre-right National and libertarian Act parties on the edge of drawing enough support to govern. The only remaining question was whether would be forced to bring a third party – populist New Zealand First – into their governing deal.

;

;The results were a forceful rejection of centre-left Labour as voters punished the governing party from both the right and the left.

;

;With more than 80% of the votes counted, the centre-right National party, led by Chris Luxon, was predicted to gain 50 seats. With Act's predicted 12, and New Zealand First's 8, that would comfortably give the right bloc 70 seats – eight more than the 61 needed to meet the threshold to govern.

;
;

;;Related: ;;New Zealand election 2023 live results: National takes strong lead; 'nightmare' for Labour, analyst says – latest updates;

;
;

;New Zealand's shift to the right ends Labour's six years in office, which oversaw the Covid-19 pandemic, the Christchurch mosque attacks and the Whakaari volcano eruption, and would firmly draw a line under Jacinda Ardern's era of politics.

;

;It is an extraordinary change in fortune for the party, which in 2020 – then under Ardern's leadership – was voted into power in a landslide, giving it the biggest mandate in nearly 30 years.

;

;But the country has revealed its mood for change in the years since that historic victory. The rising cost of living and post-pandemic malaise has translated into dissatisfaction with the political status quo, and the party's leader, Chris Hipkins failed to amass the extraordinary popularity of his predecessor, Ardern, who resigned as prime minister in January.

;

;Former political editor at news outlet Stuff, Henry Cooke, has called it “a nightmare result” for Labour, who are bleeding seats to both National and the Green party.

;

;“In several Auckland safe seats Labour are behind National after the Greens ran a fairly strong campaign in some of the seats – and National did very well.”

;

;Opinion polls in the lead up to the election had the populist minor party New Zealand First once again ;in the kingmaker position;, and there is reasonable chance National and Act will still need them, once the special votes comes in and if there is an “overhang” from Te Pāti Māori winning the six Māori electorate seats.

;

;If Te Pāti Māori win more electorate seats than their total party vote, then New Zealand's mixed member proportional system (MMP) creates an “overhang” – meaning in addition to the usual 120 seats there could be another few seats, so 122 or 123 seats. The upcoming by-election in Port Waikato will create another one. This would create 124 seats in parliament, requiring 63 seats to govern instead of 61.

;

;Winston Peters remained optimistic when speaking to his party-faithful at his election night event.

;

;“When New Zealand First said a few years ago that we were going to make a comeback, they all laughed at us – they're not laughing now are they?”

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 18:22:01 +0800 Michael Caine confirms his retirement at the age of 90https://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/14/michael-caine-confirms-his-retirement-at-the-age-of-90
;;2023-10-14T08:48:29Z;
;
;;Michael Caine pictured in 2018
;

;Michael Caine has confirmed his retirement at the age of 90, drawing to a close a glittering career in which he won two Oscars.

;

;After his comments last month that he was “sort of retired”, Caine made it official, telling the BBC's Today programme: “I keep saying I'm going to retire. Well I am now.
;
; “I've figured, I've had a picture where I've played the lead and had incredible reviews … What am I going to do that will beat this?”

;

;Caine said he wanted to end his film career, which has spanned seven decades, on a high note: “The only parts I'm liable to get now are 90-year-old men. Or maybe 85. They're not going to be the lead. 90后不再有男主角，而是有年轻帅气的少男少女。 So I thought, I might as well leave with all this.”

;

;He had previously spoken about his plans for retirement and had hinted that The Great Escaper would be his final film.

;

;But it is hardly the first time a Caine film has been billed as his last appearance, with both Harry Brown in 2009 and Best Sellers in 2021 described as such. And this announcement comes a month after he told the Guardian that he will play Charles Darwin in a film due to be shot next year.

;

;Caine plays ;Bernard Jordan; in the movie, a real-life Royal Navy veteran who ;made headlines; in 2014 when he left his care home in Hove, East Sussex, alone to attend celebrations in Normandy for the 70th anniversary of D-day.

; ;

;He stars alongside Glenda Jackson, who completed filming months before her death in June, and John Standing, who plays the fictional role of a former RAF pilot he befriends on the ferry.

;

;Caine and Jackson first worked together on the 1975 film The Romantic Englishwoman, and Caine said that while they got on, he didn't share her leftwing politics. Jackson was a Labour MP for more than two decades.

;

;“She is a very leftwing politician. And she'd like me, but she wouldn't want to mix with me socially. Because I was obviously wealthy and everything, and not a spitting socialist,” Caine said, adding that he had voted for Tony Blair.

;

;He has previously spoken of their political differences, ;telling the Guardian; last month: “I'm all for making money because I come from a very poor background.”

; ;

;Caine told Today he had turned down a role after filming The Great Escaper: “I was sent a script actually, and I looked at it, and then I did something I've never done before. I counted how many pages I had, compared to the number of pages in the script,” The role he was offered included 15 pages of dialogue in a 99-page script, he said.

;

;“I thought, I think that counts as a small part, I'm not doing it. So I retired … I thought, I'm ahead here, I may do a little part and get a bad review … so I thought, why not leave now? So I've left.”

;

;One of the best known and loved British film stars of the past 60 years, Caine has appeared in more than 130 films, including Zulu, Alfie, The Italian Job and Sleuth.

;

;He won supporting actor Oscars for his performances in Hannah and Her Sisters and The Cider House Rules, and more recently has collaborated with the director Christopher Nolan.

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 17:22:01 +0800 Australia rejects proposal to recognise Aboriginal people in constitutionhttps://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/oct/14/australia-rejects-proposal-to-recognise-aboriginal-people-in-constitution
;;2023-10-14T08:53:24Z;
;
;;Yes campaigners react the to the failed referendum in Sydney.
;

;Australians have resoundingly rejected a proposal to recognise Aboriginal people in its constitution and establish a body to advise parliament on Indigenous issues.

;

;Saturday's voice to parliament referendum failed, with the defeat clear shortly after polls closed.

;

;To succeed, the yes campaign – advocating for the voice – needed to secure a double majority, meaning it needed both a majority of the national vote, as well majorities in four of Australia's six states.

;

;The defeat will be seen by Indigenous advocates as a blow to what has been a hard fought struggle to progress reconciliation and recognition in modern Australia, with First Nations people continuing to suffer discrimination, poorer health and economic outcomes.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Voice referendum live results: votes count and map by state in the Australian Indigenous voice to parliament 2023 poll;

;
;

;More than 17 million Australians were enrolled for the compulsory vote, with many expats visiting embassies around the world in the weeks leading up to Saturday's poll.

;

;The vote occurred 235 years on from British settlement, 61 years after Aboriginal Australians were granted the right to vote, and 15 years since a landmark prime ministerial apology for harm caused by decades of government policies including the forced removal of children from Indigenous families.

;

;The referendum had been a key promise that Labor party took to the federal election in 2022, when it returned to power after years of conservative rule.

;

;Support for the voice to parliament had been strong in the early months of 2023, polling showed, but subsequently began a slow and steady decline.

;

;All major polls had foreshadowed that the no campaign would succeed and the voice would be rejected. Nationwide support for the voice was hovering at about 40% in the week before the vote, with coverage of the campaign being overshadowed by the outbreak of war in the Middle East in the crucial final days.

;

;The concept for the advisory body, which would have included Indigenous representatives from each of Australia's six states and two territories voted in by their local Indigenous electors, was developed and endorsed by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leaders in 2017. A majority of Indigenous voters supported the proposal, according to polling.

;

;It was envisaged to provide Australia's government with non-binding advice on issues affecting about 4% of the population who identify as Indigenous.

;

;There is an eight-year gap in life expectancy for Indigenous Australians compared with non-Indigenous Australians, a suicide rate twice the national average, and comparatively poorer outcomes for health, education and infant mortality.

; ;

;While such an advisory body could have been created through legislation, the proposal was designed to enshrine its existence in the constitution so it could not be removed by future governments.

;

;The referendum question, to amend Australia's constitution to recognise the first peoples of Australia by establishing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander voice to parliament, was deliberately vague. The failure of Australia's previous referendum in 1999 – to become a republic and acknowledge Indigenous ownership – was seen to have failed because it put forward a specific model to voters.

;

;Exactly what the voice advisory body would look like and how it would function were to be determined only once the concept had won approval.

;

;Opposition to the voice seized on this ambiguity, adopting a campaign slogan of “if you don't know, vote no”.

;

;But reasons for the decline in support were broad.

; ;

;The prime minister, Anthony Albanese, and his ministers were prominent faces of the yes movement, and while Labor did not lead the campaign, the government's focus on the referendum was seen alongside its handling of other national issues.

;

;It weathered accusations that it championed the voice push while failing to deliver tangible improvements for citizens facing cost of living pressures and a housing crisis hurt the yes side.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Our hearts are open': Australians head to the polls for historic voice to parliament referendum;

;
;

;Meanwhile, the Liberal party in opposition formally backed the no vote, with senior Indigenous members speaking out against the voice.

;

;Arguments against the proposal included that no such representative body was needed, that it was introducing race into the constitution, and that the voice would divide the nation.

;

;Opposition also emerged from the far left of progressive politics and a minority of grassroots Indigenous activists, who rejected the voice while calling for more significant reconciliation measures, including a treaty with Aboriginal Australians.

;

;Indigenous advocates from each side of the debate reported receiving a surge in racist abuse and prominent Aboriginal personalities across Australian media also complained of the toxic nature of debate and online vitriol.

;The company that owns the salvage rights to the Titanic shipwreck has cancelled ;plans to retrieve more artefacts; from the site because the leader of the upcoming expedition died in the Titan ;submersible implosion;, according to documents filed in a US district court this week.

;

;The decision could affect a looming court battle between the company and the US government, which ;has been trying to stop; the 2024 mission. US attorneys have said the firm's original plans to enter the ship's hull would violate a federal law that treats the wreck as a gravesite.

;

;Frenchman ;Paul-Henri Nargeolet; was the director of underwater research for RMS Titanic Inc (RMST), the Georgia-based firm that recovers and exhibits Titanic artefacts. Nargeolet was lending his expertise to a ;separate company, OceanGate;, when ;he and four others; died on the Titan's final dive near the Titanic in the north Atlantic in June.

;
;

;;Related: ;;From the archive: The Titanic is sunk, with great loss of life;

;
;

;Before Titan's tragic dive, ;RMST planned to take images; inside and outside the wreck. The firm also wanted to retrieve items from the debris field as well as freestanding objects within the sunken ocean liner.

;

;Nargeolet was supposed to be in charge. The former French navy officer ;had already completed 37 dives; and supervised the recovery of about 5,000 Titanic artefacts. RMST's exhibits have displayed items ranging from silverware to a piece of the ship's hull.

;

;The company's original 2024 expedition plan also included possibly retrieving objects from the ship's famed Marconi room. That's where the Titanic's radio transmitter broadcast increasingly frantic distress signals after the ocean liner hit an iceberg.

;

;The messages in morse code were picked up by other ships and receiving stations onshore, which helped to save the lives of about 700 people who managed to flee in lifeboats. There were 2,208 passengers and crew on the Titanic's ;1912 doomed maiden voyage; from Southampton, England, to New York.

;

;The company said on Wednesday in its court filing that its plans now only include imaging at the wreck site and surveys to refine “future artifact recovery”.

;

;“Out of respect for PH Nargeolet and his family, and the other four people who perished so recently at the site, and their families, the company has decided that artifact recovery would not be appropriate at this time,” the firm wrote.

;

;RMST also said it will not send another crewed submersible to the Titanic until “further investigation takes place regarding the cause of the [OceanGate] tragedy”. The US Coast Guard ;is leading the probe; into the ;Titan's implosion;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'You are going to kill someone': multiple warnings about Titan sub were ignored;

;
;

;The court case hinges on federal law and a pact between the US and Britain to treat the sunken Titanic as a memorial to the more than 1,500 people who died.

;

;In August, the US argued in court filings that entering the Titanic's severed hull – or physically altering or disturbing the wreck – is regulated by the law and its agreement with Britain. Among the government's concerns was the possible disturbance of artefacts ;and any human remains; that may still exist.
